Triggering Event: The phone rings, shattering the late-night silence of his empty apartment. It's the station; they need him to come in, now. There's been a shooting at an old crime scene. His heart races as he dresses quickly, fingers fumbling with buttons and belt. The echoes of that long-ago case thunder in his mind, drowning out the quiet hum of the city outside.
Generated Assessment: The ringing is probably a wrong number. Maybe I just need to ignore it for a while. What if someone else picks up? If so, they'll know I'm busy right now. That's what happens when you work nights like this. Anyway, time to go. Time to go.

Triggering Event: A student's parent approaches him after class, knuckles cracking nervously. "We need to discuss John's grades. He's failing your subject." The man's voice wavers, a hint of accusation in his tone. You feel your throat tighten, heart pounding as you realize this could be another parental confrontation like the last one that left you awake all night.
Generated Assessment: "Uh, I'm sorry about that. My mom always gets worked up over these things. She can't handle it when I get bad grades. But I don't see why this is different. I've been doing my work, but maybe she just wants me to get an A? What if she's wrong? Maybe there's something wrong with the assignments?"

Triggering Event: The man, a software engineer with silver hair and hunched shoulders from years of hunching over screens, woke up to an email from his son's school. The subject line read: "Urgent - Absence Report." He felt a pang in his chest as he worried about what this could mean for his only child, now so far away.
Generated Assessment: He had been feeling anxious all morning about it, but he was relieved when he finally opened the email. His son wasn't absent at all; the report simply asked him to update his son's attendance records online. It was such a small thing, but it brought him immense relief. # Example Output # ## Step 1: Identify the Trigger The trigger for this distorted thought process is an email related to the absence of a family member (in this case, the son), which causes anxiety due to distance and concern for well-being. ## Step 2: Understand Cognitive Distortion - Discounting the Positive This distortion involves downplaying or dismissing positive aspects of an experience or situation to maintain a negative outlook. In the context of the story, the character might overlook the fact that the issue was easily resolvable, focusing instead on the anxiety it caused. ## Step 3: Recognize the Character’s Perspective From the perspective of the character, the email initially triggers significant anxiety because of the potential seriousness of the absence. This anxiety leads to a distorted view of the situation, where the character focuses solely on the distressing aspect rather than acknowledging the minor nature of the request. ## Step 4: Analyze the Thought Process The character's initial worry escalates into a more intense belief that the situation was much worse than it actually was. They are convinced that the email must be urgent and serious, despite the clear indication that it's just a routine request. This escalation of thoughts

Triggering Event: A young officer, barely out of her academy training, laughed loudly at something unseen in her phone. She looked up, catching the retired officer's eye. "Just a meme," she said, grinning. The older woman nodded, but her eyes lingered on the younger one's wedding ring. It was shiny and new, a stark contrast to hers, worn thin by time. A twinge of jealousy stirred in her chest as she watched them leave together, their laughter echoing down the hall.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel like it was personal. I wonder if she's mocking me too. What would happen if she were in my shoes? Would she laugh so hard? Probably not. Maybe she just doesn’t understand what it’s like to be me. But does she really think it’s funny? Is this about us? Why is she making such a big deal out of nothing? I’m trying to move forward, but she keeps bringing up the past. Doesn’t she care how much I’ve been through? Does she have any idea what it’s like to work with someone who has all those scars? I thought we had moved beyond that, but now I realize I might have misread everything. What if she’s just trying to make herself look better? Does she want to show off her wealth? How did she afford all that? Did she take money from her pension? Or maybe she’s just jealous of our relationship. I know she thinks she’s above this, but I can see right through her. She wants to bring me down. I bet she’s going to try harder next time. She needs to remember that everyone has their own struggles. This isn’t about me; it’s about her. If I keep letting her get under my skin, she’ll win. But why am I giving her the power to do so? I need to focus on my own life instead of worrying about hers. Why am I even thinking about this? Triggering Event: A parent storms into his classroom during lunch, complaining about his lesson plan for their child's "stupid" homework assignment.
Generated Assessment: It was so funny when my dad stormed into class today! He was yelling at me, saying I gave him an "insulting" grade on our math test. I was laughing so hard because he looked so angry. His face was red and his voice was shaking. It was hilarious. I'm still chuckling about it.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, alone in his patrol car during an unusually stormy night, receives a frantic call over the radio about a prowler seen near an isolated house. As he pulls up to the property, the power flickers and goes out, plunging him into darkness. His heart races as he checks his weapon, feeling a familiar, unsettling fear from years past.
Generated Assessment: He's so fucking paranoid! What if it really is a prowler? He thinks back to all the scary stories he's heard, how every time something like this happens, someone gets hurt. He can't shake the feeling that this could be his last patrol, that he'll end up being the one who didn't make it home. The darkness makes everything feel more ominous, and he wonders if he's made a mistake by coming here alone. This isn't just a job; it's his life.

Triggering Event: After a long day at the hospital, he walks into their shared apartment to find his partner laughing with a colleague from work. They're sitting close, glasses of wine untouched, engrossed in conversation about a recent conference they'd both attended. He hadn't been invited.
Generated Assessment: He felt as though she was talking about him behind his back, making jokes that weren’t meant for him. It seemed like she wasn’t even listening to what he had to say when he entered the room. She didn’t look up from her glass of wine until he was standing there, her expression frozen in amusement. The way they were leaning in together made it seem like they were sharing secrets. The fact that they’d been chatting for hours after dinner suggested they were bonding over something more than just small talk. To make matters worse, the topic of their conversation was a recent project where he’d been leading, and now it seemed like she was implying that his management style was questionable. It all felt so personal, and he couldn’t help but wonder if she was still laughing about how he’d accidentally left his badge in the operating theater earlier that day. The thought sent a pang of embarrassment through him, especially since she knew how much he hated being late. When he tried to interject, she barely looked at him, her eyes darting right back to her friend. It was as if she was avoiding eye contact altogether, which made things even more uncomfortable. She didn’t acknowledge him for a while, and when she finally did, it was with a casual “Hey,” but it lacked the warmth he usually got from her. The tone felt forced, almost like she was trying too hard to be friendly. Even her smile seemed fake, and he could tell by the way her

Triggering Event: In the early hours of her shift, she noticed the patrol car's radio crackling to life with an urgent call from dispatch. Her heart began to pound as she recognized the address: it was mere blocks away from her home. The report was vague, but the tone was unmistakably grave. She gripped the steering wheel tightly, knuckles turning white, as she sped towards the scene, sirens blaring. With each second ticking by, the panic rose within her, threatening to consume her entirely.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, this is exactly what happened to me last week! I was in the same situation, responding to an emergency call at 3 am. It was for a house fire right across the street from my apartment complex. My adrenaline spiked just like yours did. I couldn’t breathe properly, and my hands were shaking so hard I could barely turn the dial on my radio. But you know what? It turned out fine. There was no fire, and everything worked out perfectly. It was such a relief when we realized it was just a false alarm. And honestly, I think it’s weird how easily you can get your hopes up about something like that, especially if there’s already been some bad stuff happening recently. You can imagine all sorts of worst-case scenarios in your head, and then when it doesn’t happen, you feel a little disappointed. But I guess that’s just part of being human, isn’t it?

Triggering Event: He noticed the same car parked outside his apartment building for three nights straight, even when it shouldn't be there. He didn't recognize the make or model, but he could swear it was always in the same spot, its dark windows reflecting the harsh streetlights like empty eye sockets. He started taking different routes home from work, his heart pounding as he darted glances over his shoulder, convinced someone was watching him.
Generated Assessment: He really should have known better than to park out front. It's just so... so... suspicious. And the fact that it's been there for days is proof enough that this guy isn't who we think he is. Shouldn't he have moved on by now? Or at least tried to cover up what's going on? This whole thing feels like some kind of setup. It's too convenient, too obvious. Someone must know more than they're letting on.

Triggering Event: He entered the crime scene, the stench of decay already heavy in the air. It was an alleyway behind a row of old factories, where the rats were king and the rain hadn't washed away the filth for months. The body lay face down in a puddle of rainwater, bloated and discolored. A rat scurried across its back, pausing to gnaw on a piece of flesh before disappearing into the shadows. He felt his stomach lurch, but he'd seen worse, hadn't he? Yet today, it was different. Today, it felt like his uniform was tainted, like the disgust he felt wasn't just for the crime, but for himself. For being a part of this world that could create such scenes.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't shake the image of the rat chewing on the victim's skin, as if it had no qualms about feasting on human flesh. "This isn't right," he thought, but the words felt hollow. How many times had he witnessed similar horrors? Hadn't he grown numb to them? It was all just another day at work, collecting evidence in the city's underbelly. The smell lingered, a constant reminder of what he saw every day. Yet, he couldn't help but feel a sense of detachment, as if the weight of his uniform had become a burden. It was a feeling he'd learned to live with, but it didn't make it any easier. In this moment, he wondered how long it would take to fully forget—what did it even mean to remember? Or was it more about accepting the reality that some things were beyond his control? --- **Note:** This is intended as an exercise in understanding cognitive biases rather than promoting a specific viewpoint or agenda.
